measured_by: 4-point confidence self-report scale (Not at all confident … Very confident)
justification: The survey asked: “Based on the pre-arrival information you saw, how confident are you about your answer? [Not at all confident; Low confidence; Confident; Very confident]”, identifying confidence as a construct captured with this four-level scale.

measured_by: 5-point typicality self-report scale (Very atypical … Very typical)
justification: Participants rated, “how representative or typical was that patient…? [Very atypical; Atypical; Neither typical nor atypical; Typical; Very Typical]”, showing typicality was operationalised with a five-point scale.

measured_by: Response time in seconds from option display to first impression
justification: The paper states, “Answer fluency was measured as the response time for the impression; timing commenced from when the options were presented and stopped with the participant's first recorded impression.”

measured_by: Forced-choice question selecting one of four diagnoses (ACS, RTI, musculoskeletal injury, pulmonary embolism)
justification: Question 1 asked, “what do you think is most likely to be wrong with the patient? (Choose one option)… [Acute Coronary Syndrome; Respiratory Tract Infection; Musculoskeletal injury; Pulmonary embolism]”; this item served as the measure of the participant’s diagnostic impression.
Experience was treated as a variable: “Years of experience… The paramedic group was divided according to the median: Less experienced (<13 years) and More Experienced (>= 13 years).”
